item.title: That New Silent Hill 2 Movie Has A Horrific 7% On Rotten Tomatoes
item.content:encoded:
Return to Silent Hill, a live-action film adaptation of Konamiâ€™s beloved Silent Hill 2, hits theaters later this week. Early reviews for the horror flick are as scary as any monster from the games.

First announced in 2022, Return to Silent Hill releases on January 23. It isnâ€™t connected to the past two Silent Hill movies, even though it was directed by the first filmâ€™s Christophe Gans, and is instead a loose adaptation of the PS2-era survival horror classic Silent Hill 2. Marketing for this film has been minimal to say the least, partially because it seems the executives involved realized it wasnâ€™t great back when it wrapped filming in 2023, and the movie is only seeing the light of day after that recent Silent Hill 2 remake did so well. But after the delay and the lack of marketing, perhaps this is a very good horror film? Nope. Doesnâ€™t seem like it.

As of January 21, there are 15 reviews for Return to Silent Hill on critic aggregator Rotten Tomatoes. And the new movie has an abysmal seven percent Tomatometer score. For those not familiar with Rotten Tomatoes, that ainâ€™t a great score. In fact, if this seven percent score holds, Return to Silent Hill will go down as one of the worst-reviewed movies ever. Yikes.

The general consensus from critics is that while parts of Return to Silent Hill look great, the film is a boring, sloppy, confusing, and (perhaps worst of all for the genre) not-very-scary movie about a main character that is hard to relate to and who seems more confused than terrified.

â€œThis powerful survival horror story has been turned into an ugly, laughable adaptation that proves that maybe we shouldâ€™ve never gone back to Silent Hill,â€ said Ross Bonaime over at Collider.

â€œChristophe Gansâ€™s film does away with all the psychosexual nuance of Silent Hill 2,â€ claims Justin Clark at Slant Magazine. 

â€œI found the experience difficult to sit through and nonsensical from moment to moment, with its confounding story and shoddy CGI matched only by its lack of entertainment value,â€ said critic Brian Eggert.

At the moment, there is only one non-rotten score, from Dominic Baez at the Seattle Times, and it doesnâ€™t read like a loving endorsement of the movie. Instead, it seems like Baez found most of the movie bad, but enjoyed the ending. The end credits are apparently very â€œstylish.â€ When critics are praising your credits and not much else, thatâ€™s a bad sign.

item.title: This Is The Worst Part Of Borderlands 4
item.content:encoded:
Despite the performance issues, annoying jokes, and bugs, Iâ€™m still playing and enjoying Borderlands 4. Iâ€™m currently working on my second full playthrough with my wife, who is also a big Borderlands fan, and weâ€™re having a great time. Mostly. Everything is going fine right up until we encounter another damn loot capsule. These things are the worst part of the game and are so bad that they truly baffle me.

As you explore the open world of Borderlands 4, youâ€™ll find side activities and quests to complete. Some of these are elaborate, but other stuff is as simple as killing a specific target or activating a safehouse. One of these supposedly simple and fun little side activities involves Loot Capsules. These are small pods that you can stumble upon and then have to carry back to the nearest safehouse to unlock. Doing so opens the capsule, and you get some loot. Sounds fine, right? Wrong!

In Borderlands 4, Gearbox created a new mechanic that lets you pick up objects while fighting. This is used in various ways in the looter shooter, and most of the time, it is a nice way to spice up a combat encounter or make solving a puzzle just a bit more interesting. But when you hold something in Borderlands 4, you canâ€™t mantle or climb up a ladder, drive your hover bike, aim down your sights, throw grenades, or fast travel with that object. It greatly limits your toolbox, and thatâ€™s fine when itâ€™s used sparingly as a momentary wrinkle you have to contend with.

Yet that isnâ€™t the case with Loot Capsules, which sometimes require you to walk a very long distance back to the â€œclosestâ€ HQ to get your reward. And you have to walk it. You canâ€™t use your cool bike. You just run back on foot, unable to take most shortcuts because you canâ€™t even use your sick grapple hook when holding an item. It is so fucking tedious. If you get attacked by enemies and have to fight your way out, youâ€™d better hope that nothing happens that dislodges that capsule from your hand, or you could be searching around desperately for it in a moment. Has this happened to me? Yes, why do you think Iâ€™m writing this blog? And when you finally get to your HQ, you might have to solve some platforming puzzle that even involves tossing the damn loot pod across gaps. If it lands in an area you canâ€™t enter, like a bottomless gorge that kills you, then it respawns back where you found it. Congratulations, you get to do it all over again.

Oh, and every time you pick it up, Claptrap starts talking. Every. Single. Time. Sometimes, heâ€™ll talk over himself. And there are only so many lines. And they go on and on. I donâ€™t even hate Claptrap like a lot of people do, but I quickly reached my breaking point after just a few capsules.

These damn capsules annoy me so much, and I deal with them so often that Iâ€™ve started to overthink how they even work. In a sci-fi universe that lets me digitize dozens of guns and store them on my person easily, why the fuck canâ€™t I just store the capsule, too? Why must I lug it back? Why canâ€™t I collect it like all the various shields, guns, and other loot I stuff into my digital trousers with no issue? Who thought this was fun? Iâ€™d love to chat with them because Iâ€™m genuinely curious how this was left in the game. Truly, it baffles me.

Hereâ€™s the funniest part about all of this: Iâ€™d be fine with the bullshit and the capsules if the reward was worth it. In my experience, this is never the case. Iâ€™ve opened close to two dozen of these things or more while playing alone and with friends. Iâ€™ve never gotten a single legendary weapon. Never. Itâ€™s usually the same crappy loot you often find in random chests, which donâ€™t require a tenth of the effort to open. Iâ€™ve talked to friends about it and theyâ€™ve reported the same thing: Worthless loot that you trash the second you see it.

At this point, Iâ€™ve started to ignore them when playing Borderlands 4 alone. And when I do pick one up, I just gnash my teeth the whole time as I hear the same damn Claptrap line again. At least I enjoy the rest of the game. Mostly.
